Unconditional Quantile Regression and Treatment Effects: Intuition and Practice

quantile-regression
treatment-effects
Published

October 31, 2024

Background

Quantile regression is a widely used tool to explore how covariates influence the distribution of an outcome variable. However, standard quantile regression focuses on conditional quantiles â€” that is, the effect of predictors on the quantiles of the outcome given the covariates. But what if your scientific question concerns unconditional (marginal) quantiles â€” the quantiles of the overall outcome distribution?

This is where Unconditional Quantile Regression (UQR), developed by Firpo, Fortin, and Lemieux (2009), enters the scene. Instead of modeling the conditional quantile function directly, UQR uses a clever trick: it regresses the recentered influence function (RIF) of the outcome on the covariates. This approach allows us to estimate the impact of covariates on unconditional quantiles, providing insight into how changes in the distribution of predictors shift the entire distribution of the outcome.

This article explains the intuition, core mechanics, estimation strategies, and practical issues of UQR, focusing especially on applications in treatment effects estimation.

Notation

Consider an outcome variable ( Y ) and covariates ( X ). We are interested in the ( )-th quantile ( q_{} ) of the unconditional distribution of ( Y ).

The influence function for the ( )-th quantile is:

[ IF(Y; q_{}) = , ]

where ( f_Y(q_{}) ) is the density of ( Y ) at the quantile point.

The recentered influence function (RIF) is defined as:

[ RIF(Y; q_{}) = q_{} + IF(Y; q_{}). ]

A Closer Look

Why Use Unconditional Quantile Regression?

Unlike conditional quantile regression, UQR tells us how shifts in the distribution of predictors affect the overall distribution of outcomes â€” not just within fixed levels of covariates. This matters in policy evaluation where interventions might change the covariate distribution itself (e.g., unionization rates, education levels).

The intuition is simple but powerful: by regressing ( RIF(Y; q_{}) ) on covariates ( X ), we obtain estimates of Unconditional Quantile Partial Effects (UQPEs) â€” the marginal effect of shifting ( X ) on the unconditional quantiles of ( Y ).

Estimation

The estimation proceeds in three steps: 1. Estimate the sample quantile ( q_{} ). 2. Estimate the density ( f_Y(q_{}) ), typically via kernel density estimation. 3. Construct the RIF for each observation and regress it on the covariates.

The basic regression is:

[ RIF(Y; q_{}) = Xâ€™ + , ]

where ( ) now captures the effect of ( X ) on the ( )-th unconditional quantile.

The most common implementation is RIF-OLS, though alternatives include RIF-Logit and nonparametric first stages (RIF-NP).

Inference and Challenges

  • Density Estimation: A critical step that affects the quality of inference. Poor density estimation at the quantile point can lead to noisy estimates.
  • Nonlinearity and Model Misspecification: RIF-OLS assumes a linear relationship between the RIF and covariates. If the true relationship is nonlinear, flexible methods (logit, nonparametric) are preferred.
  • Standard Errors: Because of the multi-step estimation (quantile, density, RIF), standard error computation is more complex. Bootstrapping is commonly used.
  • Treatment Effects: UQR is especially appealing for estimating treatment effects on the distribution of outcomes. When treatment is exogenous, including treatment indicators in the RIF regression yields estimates of the treatment effect at various unconditional quantiles.

Strengths and Applications

UQR shines in settings where the policy question concerns distributional effects, such as: - Wage inequality and labor economics. - Health outcomes across the full distribution. - Policy evaluation where shifting the covariate distribution is plausible.

It also generalizes to other distributional statistics (Gini, variance) by using the corresponding influence functions.

An Example

::::

R

library(dplyr)
library(quantreg)
library(KernSmooth)

set.seed(123)
n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n)
y <- 2 + 0.5 * x + rnorm(n)
q_tau <- quantile(y, 0.5)
f_y <- bkde(y)$y[which.min(abs(bkde(y)$x - q_tau))]
rif <- q_tau + (0.5 - as.numeric(y <= q_tau)) / f_y
model <- lm(rif ~ x)
summary(model)

Python

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import statsmodels.api as sm
from scipy.stats import gaussian_kde

np.random.seed(123)
n = 1000
x = np.random.randn(n)
y = 2 + 0.5 * x + np.random.randn(n)
q_tau = np.quantile(y, 0.5)
kde = gaussian_kde(y)
f_y = kde.evaluate(q_tau)[0]
rif = q_tau + (0.5 - (y <= q_tau).astype(int)) / f_y
X = sm.add_constant(x)
model = sm.OLS(rif, X).fit()
print(model.summary())

::::

Bottom Line

  • UQR estimates the effects of predictors on unconditional quantiles â€” a complement to conditional quantile regression.
  • It uses the recentered influence function to connect regression modeling with distributional statistics.
  • Careful attention to density estimation and inference is needed.
  • Especially useful for policy analysis and distributional treatment effect estimation.

Where to Learn More

The foundational paper by Firpo, Fortin, and Lemieux (2009) is the key resource for understanding UQR. For more practical applications, look into recent literature on RIF regressions in labor economics, health economics, and policy analysis.

References

  • Firpo, S., Fortin, N. M., & Lemieux, T. (2009). Unconditional Quantile Regressions. Econometrica, 77(3), 953â€“973.
